text:
Some time ago, there was a website that talked about the risks of public check-ins. It said that if you post your location online, people you don't know can see it. This made people realize that there are some downsides to sharing everything on the internet.
The internet has a lot of opportunities for people to share their lives. You can write a blog, post photos, and share your thoughts with the world. But you should be careful about what you share online. If you put your personal information on the internet, people might be able to find it and use it against you.
There are some people who have learned from the mistakes of others. Heather Armstrong is one of them. She had a blog where she wrote about her life. One day, someone sent the address of her blog to her boss. As a result, she lost her job. But Armstrong didn't give up. She started a new blog and wrote about her family. Today, she is a successful blogger and her writing supports her family.

A long time ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a movie called What the Bleep Do We Know. The movie showed that there is a lot about the universe that we don't understand. Some scientists felt that the movie was dangerous and issued warnings about it. The movie was very popular, but I couldn't see what all the fuss was about at first. However, when the movie moved on to describe some of the new discoveries, I started to see what the fuss was really about. One of the discoveries was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard rumours about this before, but the movie gave me some evidence to support it. The evidence was not very convincing, but it was enough to make me believe that the discovery was real. The movie also talked about other discoveries, such as the discovery that the universe is made from an unknown form of matter and is being propelled by a mysterious force known only as 'dark energy'. These discoveries are amazing, but they also make me feel like we are further away from understanding the universe than ever before.

**
Writing novels is like planting a forest, while writing short stories is more like planting a garden. The two processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape that I treasure. Writing novels takes a long time and a lot of commitment, while writing short stories is quicker and easier to complete. It's like going into a room, finishing your work, and leaving. You don’t have to worry about failing. If the idea doesn’t work out, you just shrug your shoulders and move on. Short stories are like soft shadows I have set out in the world, faint footprints I have left behind. They are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to be able to share these intimate feelings with my readers.

Science is a powerful force that has both improved and threatened human existence. It has made our lives easier and has also challenged our very existence. Science has its beauty and its dangers, and it is important to understand both.
Science has been used to explain the universe and to cure disease. It has also been used to inspire artists and politicians. However, science has also been used to manipulate nature and to create weapons.
The history of science is filled with conflict and change. Scientists come in many colors, and their work is often characterized by conflict. However, science is also a force for progress and change. It has improved our ability to understand the world around us and to predict the future.
Science is not a harmless intellectual pastime. It has become part of the human race’s way of conceiving of and manipulating its future. We need to be aware of the potential dangers of science and to use science responsibly.

**
From around 2015, major publishers started to notice that sales of ebooks had stopped growing, or even fallen in some cases. This made people question whether ebooks would continue to be popular. One publishing executive admitted that the ebooks hype may have been too much, and that his company had lost confidence in the power of the printed word. Despite the evidence, the idea that ebooks will 'kill' print books continues to be discussed. It is important to understand that digital and print can coexist in the market. The potential disappearance of the book does not mean that it will cease to stimulate our imagination or provoke intense debate.
The idea of one medium 'killing' another has been used to describe many new technologies. Even before the invention of digital technologies, people predicted that existing media would die. But new technologies have often found new uses and survived. The same is true for books. As technology changes, we find ourselves longing for what we used to know, but no longer have. This is why entire industries develop around retro products and older technologies.

Every day, I wake up early to write about how some of the greatest minds of the past have approached their work. I write about their daily routines and how they made the time to do their best work. I also write about my own struggles with creativity and productivity.
I have a lot of concerns about creativity and productivity. How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to devote yourself wholly to a project or to set aside a small portion of each day? And when there doesn’t seem to be enough time for all you hope to accomplish, must you give things up or can you learn to condense activities, to do more in less time, to ‘work smarter, not harder’?
I have tried to provide examples of how a variety of brilliant and successful people have confronted many of the same challenges. I wanted to show how grand creative visions translate to small daily increments; how one’s working habits influence the work itself, and vice versa.
This book is about people’s routines. It’s about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product; it deals with manufacturing rather than meaning. But it’s also, inevitably, personal. I have documented all of my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also serve as a guide to further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because he was interested in dinosaurs. He wanted to become a palaeontologist since he was young. He studied delicate creatures revealed on the surface of grey rocks. He worked on his doctoral thesis and got a job as an Assistant Lecturer at Tavistock College in London. He was surprised at the evident favouritism from a man he did not know. But he was grateful that he had the job and could support himself by doing the sort of work he wanted to do.

Charles Spence is a Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. He has studied how the senses interact to form our perception of flavour. Through his studies, he has influenced what we eat and drink. He has also studied how the environment affects taste.
Spence has written a book called The Perfect Meal, which is packed with insights about food and drink. It is a fascinating book for anyone who loves to eat and drink.
Spence's lab is not very high-tech. It has soundproof booths and stacks of ancient-looking audio-visual equipment. He can afford to work more creatively with cooks because he keeps his overheads low.
Spence has been helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. He says that it is in their interests to help loyal customers stay alive for longer.
Spence has also studied the effects of sound on flavour. He has found that higher-pitched music enhances sweetness, and lower-pitched and brassy sounds make food taste bitter.

Our brains are very busy these days. We have a lot of information to deal with, including facts, rumors, and things that are not true. We also do more things ourselves now than we used to. For example, we make our own reservations and find things in shops. We do a lot of different things at once, but it's not always easy to keep up with everything. Our smartphones help us do all of this, but they also make it harder to focus.
When we think we're multitasking, we're actually switching from one task to another very quickly. This is not very efficient. Multitasking can also make us feel stressed and anxious. It can also make it harder to learn new information. If you do your homework and watch TV at the same time, the information from your schoolwork will not go to the right part of your brain.
Multitasking also requires a lot of decision-making. This can be very tiring for our brains. If we make a lot of small decisions, we can end up making a big decision that is not very well thought out. This is because our brains are not wired to multitask well. We are more like amateur plate spinners, frantically switching from one task to another, ignoring the one that’s not right in front of us but worried it’ll come crashing down any minute.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino would break up concrete into pieces at night and throw them at visitors during the day. Was he being spiteful? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Are they being caring? Fifty years ago, people thought that animals didn’t have consciousness, feelings or moral systems. But recently that has partially changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, and other animals, emotions of animals have gone from being a taboo area of investigation to being tentatively explored. It is a change that has in recent years filtered through the scientific strata to a selection of popular science books. And it has started a debate that may never be solved by science: can animals be said to have consciousness?
The debate about animal consciousness raises a second question: conscience – a person’s moral sense of right and wrong that guides their behaviour. In a recent experiment involving cows, it became apparent that those that successfully opened the gate themselves showed more pleasure than those that had to have the gate opened for them. If, as this research seems to imply, cows enjoy problem-solving, what does it mean for the production and consumption of beef? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is. There are different views on what the new research means for the future of meat consumption. Some people believe that we should stop eating meat altogether, while others believe that we should at the very least re-evaluate our view of animal cognition. The debate is ongoing and there is no clear answer.

Critical thinking is a way of understanding things more deeply. It involves interacting with what we read or listen to in a way that helps us to think more deeply. There is a belief that argument is a way of finding the truth. Although technology can help us store and process information, it can also make it more difficult to think critically.
There are a number of things that can make it more difficult to think critically. One is the amount of poor yet charismatic thinking that we are exposed to. Another is the overwhelming amount of information that we have access to. And finally, the fact that visual media often do not allow us to reflect or analyze information.
However, there are also some ways that technology can help us to think critically. One is the fact that it can make it easier to access information. Another is the fact that it can make it easier to connect with others who are thinking critically. And finally, the fact that it can make it easier to learn new things.
It is important to understand the subtleties of how technology affects thinking and analysis. By understanding these subtleties, we can make sure that we are using technology in a way that helps us to think critically.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing or thinking about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He wrote two books about the benefits of manual trades and how to cope with modernity.
Crawford says that our attention is being pulled away by many things, including advertisements, video games, and our phones. He also says that we are more conscious of other things we might be doing.
Crawford's proposed solution has two parts. First, we need regulation of noise and distraction in public space. More importantly, though, Crawford advocates skilled practices as a way of engaging with the world in a more satisfying way.
For example, if you like to cook, you can practice cooking. If you like to play hockey, you can practice playing hockey. If you like to ride motorcycles, you can practice riding motorcycles.

"What do you do for a living?" is a common question that people often ask. If you are a philosopher, it can be a little harder to answer this question. This is because philosophers have established themselves as people who judge the activities of others and celebrate intellectual life. They also have a lot of academic training and often write books about their ideas.
However, you don't have to be a philosopher to benefit from philosophy. You can learn from the ideas of philosophers by reading books, articles, or watching videos. You can also talk to people who are interested in philosophy.
Philosophy can help you to think more clearly about your own beliefs and values. It can also help you to understand the world around you better. If you are interested in learning more about philosophy, there are many resources available to you. You can find books, articles, and videos online. You can also talk to people who are interested in philosophy.

Foodies, gourmands, chefs and others who love food might expect that thinking critically about what and how we eat can contribute to culinary pleasure. However, historically, philosophical discussions about food have been mostly about other topics, such as the acquisition of knowledge. Sometimes, philosophical conversations about food appear to be about other things, but when you look closer, you find that they are actually about deeper, but loosely connected, points.
It is interesting to note the case of the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus, who believed that the pursuit of pleasure and the avoidance of pain should be the goal of life. Epicurus' name is often used to describe people who love to eat and drink. It is also used in the names of restaurants, food shops and online recipe sites.
Food is inherently social and cultural. It is shared with our communities and provides us with dining companions and infrastructure. We interact with food more frequently and in more fundamental ways than any other commodity. So, it is an obvious topic for philosophical enquiry.
There are also ethical issues that attach to food. We can ask what we should eat and why the answers are what they are. And philosophers will always ask why the answers are what they are. Engaging in such academic debate is fully justified in relation to food.

Rob Daviau is a US designer who creates 'legacy' board games. These games are different from traditional board games because they have a permanent impact on the game. For example, in one game called Risk Legacy, players might have to rip up cards, deface the board, or open packets containing new rules. The games play out over a fixed number of sessions and long-held grudges become woven into the fabric of the game.
Legacy board games were not expected to become popular, but most players love the concept. They see it as one of the biggest advances in game design for several years. The legacy format draws on video games and the demand for episodic entertainment fuelled by popular TV series.
Daviau feels a sense of ownership, but he is also keen to see where others take the idea. He suspects gamers will soon be asking: 'Enough of that, what's new?'

Once upon a time, there was an octopus named Inky who lived in a tank at the New Zealand National Aquarium. One night, Inky managed to escape from his tank and swim across the floor to a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. It was a story that was shared online and was very popular.
One of the reasons why people find stories like Inky's so interesting is because they involve anthropomorphism, which means treating animals like humans. In the case of octopuses, this pleasure is especially pronounced because of their intelligence and their bodies that are very different from our own.
Scientists have found that animals have many of the same abilities as humans, such as the ability to consider the past and the future, to demonstrate empathy and self-awareness, and to anticipate the motives of others. However, animals do not have fully-developed language like humans.
There are some people who believe that anthropomorphism is unscientific. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies primates, argues that it is not unscientific, but rather the opposite – an unwillingness to recognize the human-like traits of animals.
De Waal believes that we are emerging from a dark period where animals were not treated very well. He also believes that the times are changing and that people are learning to appreciate animal intelligence more.

Once upon a time, there was a technology called robotics that has the potential to change the world. Robots have already been used in the automotive and manufacturing industries for many years. Now, experts are saying that robots will soon be used in many other industries.
One of the main challenges with the widespread use of robots is that it will lead to job loss. However, experts also say that it will create new jobs. For example, there will be more demand for technicians and programmers.
Another challenge is that society is not prepared for the changes that robots will bring. For example, robots will make it easier for people to interact with each other. This could lead to changes in the way we work and socialize.
Despite the challenges, experts believe that robotics has the potential to improve our lives. For example, robots can help us to be more efficient and productive. They can also help us to live longer and healthier lives.
In order to prepare for the robotic workforce of tomorrow, we need to invest in education and training programs. We also need to develop new regulatory frameworks to ensure our safety and privacy.

Because there is a place for climbers to climb, George Mallory said that he wanted to climb Mount Everest. People often wonder why people climb mountains. It is possible that the climber’s answer may inspire some to act on their dreams. Climbing can give people a feeling of freedom, but it can also be very confining. There is an apparent paradox in many forms of climbing. However, climbing can also help cultivate important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment.
When people ask "Why climb?", US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests that a better question would be "Why do people climb?". Climbing is in our genes and it is inherent in our basic makeup to take on challenges and test limits. Climbing can also help develop important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment.

Alfred Brendel is a famous pianist who has been playing classical music for many years. He is known for his intellectual and disciplined personality. Brendel has written and played a lot of music, but he has not taught very many students. Those who knew him well saw a playful side to his character, but that was seldom on display in his concerts.
Brendel has a young student named Kit Armstrong. Kit is a talented musician who is learning from Brendel. Kit is a restless and impatient young man who is always learning new things. He is also a composer. Brendel is impressed by Kit's ability to listen to his own playing and his sensitivity to sound.
Brendel is now 80 years old and he is still playing music. He is proud of his accomplishments and he is excited about his future.

My grandparents' garden was a beautiful place. It was on the bank of a river and sloped gently down towards the water. You couldn't reach the river but you could hear the sound of the water and the birds that sang in the trees above. I imagined that all gardens were like this – a place of escape, peace and solitude.
My father was a quiet and withdrawn person. He had a few phrases that he liked to use, one of them being 'It's immaterial to me'. He was probably disappointed that he hadn't made more of his life. He left school without qualifications and became apprenticed to a plumber. Plumbing was not something he was passionate about. It was just what he did.
I always wanted to like the piano but it did its best to intimidate me. The only thing I did like about it were the two brass candlesticks that jutted out from the front. I'd walk along the river bank looking for a suitable spot where I could take off the painful sandals and leave them with my picnic while I ventured out, tentatively, peering through the water for any fish that I could scoop up with the net and take home.
One day my father announced that there was a vacancy for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested. I like to feel that somewhere deep down inside him, although he hated gardening himself, he'd watched me doing it for long enough and noticed the keenness and the passion for all things that grew and flowered and fruited that hadn't disappeared.

Lawrence MacEwen lives on the Isle of Muck, a small island in Scotland. The island is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean. There is a strong wind blowing, and it can be dangerous. But MacEwen is not worried. He is happy on his island. He has a sheepdog named Tie, and he loves his family.
The island is also home to MacEwen's farm and his family's business. They have a hotel, a restaurant, and a few cottages. The island is a beautiful place, but it also has its challenges. For example, there is no electricity or phone service. But MacEwen and his family are resilient. They have learned to cope with the challenges of living on an island.
One day, MacEwen invited me to visit his island. I stayed on the island for a few days, and I had a wonderful time. I ate well, slept well, and enjoyed the beautiful scenery. I also learned a lot about island life.

The game design industry is a competitive one, but it is also expanding. To get into the industry, you need to have a passion for games and be willing to work hard. You can start by making games on your own, or you can take a postgraduate course in games. If you want to work for a big company, you will need to have a degree in computer science. However, if you are not interested in working for a big company, you can still get involved in the industry by creating your own games or working as an artist or programmer.

**
Since I was young, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, and I'm grateful that he didn't push me too much. I had a friend who was also passionate about football, but he stopped playing and hasn't been involved in the sport since. I'm glad that I didn't have that happen to me. When I score a goal, people often say that it's just luck, but it isn't. I have worked hard to improve my skills since I was a child. If I'm teaching kids, the most important thing I try to get across is to enjoy learning skills. I used to do many different sports at school, but football was the only thing I was really passionate about. I want to make sure that my son has the same opportunities that I had. I'm not rich, but I have a lot of friends and family who support me. I also like to help others. After I stop playing football, I think I'll have a year off or perhaps even longer, doing the things I haven't been able to do all these years.

It was because of Sam Carter that we lived at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He found a cheap place for us to live. Los Angeles was not a very pleasant place to live. The weather was cold and the beach was deserted. Reef Point was not a popular place for day trippers. The road was uninviting and there was a charming little resort nearby. If you were broke or surfing mad, you would risk the last mile to get to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, the place was busy. My father was working hard to write a script. I spent a lot of time on the beach reading books and playing with my dog, Rusty. Rusty was a very friendly dog. He loved the beach and he always wanted to swim. Sometimes, he would dig up things that were not his. I had to return those things to their owners. Rusty also liked to swim. He always insisted on accompanying me, although I could swim much faster and farther than he could. We had been swimming that day. The sun was setting and it was getting cooler. We sat watching the surfers. They had been surfing all day. One surfer in particular caught my eye. She had a style that made all the others look like clumsy amateurs. But now she seemed to decide to call it a day and rode in on a final wave.

The boat was crowded with people waiting to board. There were long queues and it was difficult to get on. Some people were impatient and started to complain. Violet was also feeling frustrated because she had lost her phone and she couldn't call anyone. She was standing in the queue and she felt like she was being squashed against the side of the lift. Finally, she reached her room and she was able to relax.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he discovered the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for images to use in a book about the history of the Portage Park neighbourhood in Chicago. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a keen eye for capturing compelling images. Since then, Maloof has amassed an archive of Maier’s life and work. He has a lot of her cameras, film, prints, negatives, movies and audiotapes.
Maier was born in 1926 and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and came to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person but she had a strong interest in photography. She always had a camera with her and took pictures of people, children, the old and the poor.
Maloof often wonders if he’ll ever work his way through all the negatives. He had no real interest in photography until he discovered Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural shots, Maloof actually went out on the street and began to take his own pictures.

When a novel is described as ambitious, it usually means that it is not very successful. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. The book is set during the 1860s in New Zealand. There has been a series of crimes committed, and a council of 12 men has been convened to solve them. The plot is very complex. Catton said she set out to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past offered more opportunities for complications and misunderstandings for her characters to deal with. The book is long, but it is also very exciting and fun to read. Catton is a talented writer who is able to create a sense of atmosphere and suspense in her writing.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved to play the guitar. He learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. He studied guitars and figured out how different shapes and types of wood affected the sound. He also learned how to build his own instruments.
Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think of it as a career. He was also into painting and sculpture. He chose to study architecture at university but dropped out because he was too individualistic. He then decided to focus on his passion for sculpture and guitar-building.
Ever since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. He has to make a living by making a limited number of guitars each year. But he is still passionate about his work and believes that developing a career is more straightforward today.

Any conversation about English conversation often begins with the weather. It is a traditional thing to talk about the weather when two English people meet. This is true even today, as it was over two hundred years ago. However, most people who write about the English 'obsession' with the weather make a mistake. They assume that our conversations about the weather are actually about the weather. This is not true. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather at all. They are a form of 'grooming talk' that helps us to overcome our natural reserve and talk to each other. There are certain fixed contexts in which weather-speak is used. It can be used as a simple greeting, as an ice-breaker leading to conversation on other matters or as a 'default' or 'filler' topic when conversation on other matters dries up.

Alice Leader was standing in front of the remains of a Roman wall in Britain. She was explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds about the extraordinary feat of engineering it was to build something so long and high. She had already stimulated their interest, but they really wanted to know why it was built. Alice felt her answers were unsatisfactory. She decided to write her own novel to add context and human interest to life at the Wall in Roman times. After retiring from teaching, Alice embarked on a second career as an author. She wrote her first novel and was successful. She sees her writing as an extension of teaching.
The text has been simplified by removing unnecessary details and complex sentence structures. The vocabulary has been simplified and the text has been broken down into shorter paragraphs. The text also includes a clear and concise summary of the main points.

**
To raise money for charity, two brothers, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, were challenged to take part in a unique race. The race was held in the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England.
Jonny raced in a car on the roads, while Alistair raced across the country on a mountain bike. The race started at a beautiful lake and finished at the highest road in Yorkshire.
There were some obstacles in the race. The first obstacle was a giant tractor that lumbered out of a field and onto the road. The second obstacle was the slope of the hill that forced Alistair to dismount his bike and carry it up.
Despite the obstacles, both brothers finished the race. They were both exhausted, but they were happy that they had completed the challenge.

**
The silence at Centre Court during the Wimbledon tennis championships is very quiet. You can bounce the ball, serve, and hit it, and you hear the echo of your shot. The grass is soft and the stadium is ancient. The players wear white and the crowds are respectful. The quiet of the Centre Court is good for your game. It helps you to focus on the point you are playing and to shut everything else out.
When a point is done, there is a lot of noise. People cheer and applaud. You hear them, but it feels like they are coming from a long way away. You are so focused on the game that you don't notice the number of people watching you.
I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. I had played there before, but I had never won. In 2008, I was playing in the final again. I was confident that I had learned from my defeat in 2007 and that I would win.

In the early 1950s, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. She spent most of her life in Africa and became known for her work as a scientist, activist, and environmentalist.
Goodall's research on chimpanzees has been very influential. She discovered that chimpanzees eat meat, use tools, and have emotions like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is a leading authority on chimpanzee research.
Goodall's work has also had a significant impact on human thinking. She has helped us to understand ourselves better and our relationship to animals. Her story is an inspiration to all.

During my first conversation, Shirley Ford spoke to me in the voice of a young boy, his tired mother, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are similar to those heard on children’s TV and cartoons, and to people who have seen computerised employee programmes about health and safety.
Shirley talked about what it takes to do voiceovers. You have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. You also have to be able to create the right sounds from the back of your throat.
After school, Shirley enrolled on a drama course and had some occasional work singing jingles for TV adverts. One day, she was asked to try out for the part of a rabbit in the soundtrack for a cartoon. Amazingly, she ended up getting a major part.
Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices as she watches children’s TV. The competition for work is fierce, and a good showreel is essential.
For anyone considering a career doing voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops’ and having a passion for human sound.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. It's a dream job that many people have. But most people eventually give up on their dreams and consider more realistic professions. To become a cartoonist, you don't need a lot of money or a university degree. You just need your brain, your hand, and something that makes a mark. If you feel that doing anything else would be impossible, then cartooning might be the right job for you. But it's not easy. It's a tough job that requires a lot of hard work and dedication. If you want to be a cartoonist, you need to be creative and business-savvy. You also need to be willing to learn from your mistakes and keep practicing.

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and had a lot of things to get rid of. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had bought me for my 16th birthday. I felt sad about throwing it away, but I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of rubbish. Suddenly, a young man came up to me and asked if I was going to throw it away. I said yes and he asked if he could have it. I gave it to him and felt sad that I had thrown it away.
A few months later, I got an email from someone I didn't know. It was from a dealer and restorer of guitars called Keith Rushton. He said he had my guitar and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy to get my guitar back and I started playing it again.
I had forgotten all about my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything I had, including my guitar. My dad had been very keen for me to learn the classical guitar, but I couldn't make much progress. So I switched to the electric guitar and started playing undemanding stuff.
Now that I'm learning it again, I guess I'll have to form a band. My son's learning the saxophone; maybe I can play with him. Or maybe there are other people of my age who have had a similar experience to mine. Maybe we could call ourselves 'The Regainers'!'

There has been a lot of talk about sleep lately. Sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social well-being. It seems that people who have the hardest time sleeping appreciate how important sleep is the most.
Dreams are important too. They help us find new patterns and create combinations that break through our usual habits of thinking. When we dream, we bring things together in fresh, often surprising ways.
When we wake up from a dream, our brains are still active. We can use our dreams to help us think creatively and flexibly. We need to dream in order to function fully in our complex world.

It was twenty years ago that Susie Ray left London for a small coastal town in south-west England. She has a studio with a beautiful sea view and hangs photographs of her two daughters on the walls. Susie is a copyist artist who can reproduce the richness of an early-20th-century impressionist masterpiece as easily as the brilliance of a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait.
The problem is that Susie is very popular. She has painted the works of numerous great artists, including Renoir, Monet and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so faithful that art experts mistake them for the originals.
Susie has always been open about what she does. When she reproduces an old masterpiece, she will make it look as authentic as possible. However, she will put her own signature on the back of the canvas.
When younger painters approach Susie for advice, she stresses the importance of learning to draw and to represent things accurately. She also emphasises how much she’s studied to be able to do what she does.

Ellen MacArthur was a racer who loved the sea. She had a special connection with her boats. They worked together like one. When she was on land, she felt that life was trivial. After she won a race, she took people on a tour of her boat. She talked about the careful planning that went into provisioning and housekeeping. She also started a charity to help young people rethink and redesign a sustainable future.
The text has been simplified by removing unnecessary details and jargon, using simpler vocabulary and sentence structure, and breaking up the text into shorter paragraphs. The factual content of the original text has been preserved.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his generation. Young people are spending more time on computers and games consoles, so Jordan hopes to inspire kids to climb their own mountains. He wants to encourage kids to venture outdoors. Jordan's team for the climb includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' If Jordan can climb Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will become the youngest person to have climbed the Seven Summits. Few people achieve this under the age of thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of the Seven Summits and might actually do it before his teenage years are over.
There are some concerns about Jordan's climb. Some people think that a young climber might not be emotionally strong enough or have enough experience. But Jordan's parents believe that their own experience as climbers will help them. They also think that watching Jordan develop gives them confidence.
Jordan's motivation is also a question. Is this just an ambitious father taking his own love of adventure to a dangerous extreme? But Paul insists that this project isn't about him trying to become famous for his son's achievements. He says, 'If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he's done with mountain climbing and wants to play basketball instead, we’ll shut this whole project down and go to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's probably not classical music they're listening to. Most people our age can name a lot of pop groups, but ask any of my friends if they know who Brahms was and they probably won't have a clue. I'm doing a music degree, but the people on my course know no more about classical music than anyone else my age. If you don't know who wrote the music, you are unlikely to own any recordings of their work. The statistics are not very encouraging for a lover of classical music. Apparently only a small percentage of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells a small number of copies. I still find that hard to believe. So, what has caused this decline in interest for classical music? The main reason is that classical music just doesn't hold much attraction for most people, particularly teenagers. There are a few reasons why teenagers don't like classical music. First, the pace and rhythm of classical music are not very appealing to us. Second, classical music is structurally complex and difficult to listen to. Third, the subject matter of classical music is not very relatable to teenagers. Finally, the way we listen to music has changed. Nowadays, we can find any music we want at the click of a mouse, and the sound track to our lives is rarely classical.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mom's car and looked at Almonside School. It was a funny school with lots of buildings and trees. There was a riding centre where the horses were kept. Bonnie treated the horses with respect. She looked at each horse and judged it. She felt like a queen on a horse. She rode the horse around the paddock. The rhythm was exhilarating. She felt certain that the horse would jump well.

I met Cody Simpson a long time ago. He is a young Australian singer who has released many successful songs. He started singing when he was very young. One day, he posted some videos of himself singing on the internet. These videos became popular and people started asking for more. Cody was happy to oblige. He started recording more videos and people loved them.
But Cody was also a very talented swimmer. He was training hard and had a lot of success. However, record labels came calling and offered him a deal to move to the US and become a singer. Cody had to make a difficult decision. He had to choose between his dream of becoming a swimmer and his dream of becoming a singer.
In the end, Cody decided to take the chance and move to the US. He has been very successful as a singer. He has traveled to many countries and played in front of thousands of fans. However, Cody knows that his success will not last forever. He is grateful for his family and friends who have supported him through his journey.

I woke up early and looked at the river. The ice was shining in the sunlight. I helped my family to protect the buildings from flooding. I worked hard all last week. My grandfather didn’t notice. I saw a boy on the river bank. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf. I was going kayaking. I put on my wetsuit and jacket. I checked my lucky chain. It was a silver chain that my grandfather brought back from South America. I went to the kitchen and ate breakfast. My mom smiled at me. She said I was up early for a Saturday. I headed down the hallway and saw Grandpa. He was angry. He said I didn’t win the competition. I felt sad, but I didn’t let him get to me. I went outside and went to the boathouse.

**
Mum caught Jess by the arm and asked her to come with her to the study. There was a painting on the table, which was one of Grandpa's. It was unlike anything he had done before and clearly nowhere near finished. Mum spoke to Jess about the painting and asked her if she knew anything about it. Jess shook her head and said she had never seen it before. The picture was strange and beautiful. There was a river in the picture that was not real. The riverbank was almost insignificant. There were no animals or people in the picture. It felt right that way. Mum spoke again and said the painting had a name. The name was 'River Boy'. The words seemed to carry a strange resonance. Jess looked round at Mum and said, "There is no boy." Mum laughed and said, "Exactly. Strange, isn’t it?"
The painting was unusual because it had a name. Mum thought that it was a good painting and she was hoping that Jess might know something about it.

When I woke up this morning, I didn't mean to damage my bedroom carpet. It just seemed like a good idea at the time. I was trying to find a way of fitting my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran had given me the cabinet when she moved out of her house into a flat. It's really cute.
But the thing is, it is a corner cabinet. That is why it is shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I've only got two corners in my bedroom. I'd tried fitting Gran’s cabinet into the angle between the roof and the floor, but it was just the tiniest little bit too tall. If I could only slice a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... That was when it came to me. If I couldn’t slice anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It just seemed like the obvious solution.

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They borrow things from the normal-sized people in order to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it was going to be hard to live up to people’s expectations. The author had told me she wanted the series to be from the Borrowers' perspective, not a human one, which made filming much more complex.
The most crucial thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so I had to be much further away from the actors than I would normally be. When filming the human surroundings the Borrowers found themselves in, the crew had to crawl along the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimetres, in order to get the Borrowers' perspective.
One big challenge was finding a way to get the shadows right when the images of the supposedly tiny Borrowers were combined with a background image of ordinary-sized surroundings. We developed a unique technique for this. The costumes were also a big challenge. They had to be made out of heavy canvas material so that they stuck out in the way that dolls’ clothes do. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think either of them thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes!

Mom pulled up at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looked around nervously, searching for journalists that weren’t there. I was excited to see how long it would take before the craziness began. Because it always does. The people at the school, the wannabe friends, the people who want free tickets to one of my dad’s concerts. I told her, "Everything’s going to be fine." She kissed her fingertip and touched my cheek right before I got out of the car. Then she was off, leaving me alone with this whole new school and situation to deal with. But this is what I asked her for. To get away from my old life on the road and tour tutors. So while the rest of the band is renting here during the recording, we’re staying for good. I wanted to meet real kids for a change. How about a kid with a mom who types from nine to five in an office? Or a dad who cuts grass? That’d be so cool. So normal. I walked into the school’s main office and asked for my schedule. The secretary seemed confused. But I got my schedule and it was cool. English Literature, first period. I was late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, as I didn’t want to look like a complete buffoon searching for my classes. When I got to the door, I heard the teacher already taking roll. I slipped in undetected and slid into the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiled. She was friendly. 'Nice shoes,' she whispered. I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. Dead giveaway. 'Thanks,' I said. The teacher paused in the roll taking. 'Desert... McGraw?' she said hesitantly. 'Here.' The teacher smiled and introduced herself as Ms. Smigla. She talked a lot and eventually handed us our course outlines. After we reviewed them and she told us all about books we’re required to read this year, she actually gave us time to socialize! All teachers should realize the importance of this.

In the United States, teenage girls are expected to be Student Council presidents and have part-time jobs, volunteer, and excel in all of these fields. Being an American teenager today is challenging. Teenagers have a lot of homework, tests, and extra-curricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home. They also have to maintain a social life.
There are some negative stereotypes about teenagers, such as being lazy, disrespectful, and rebellious. However, not all teenagers are like this. Many teenagers are hardworking, responsible, and caring. They are also creative and ambitious.
Teenagers today have a lot of challenges, but they are also very resilient. They are able to overcome obstacles and achieve their goals. They are also able to make a positive impact on the world.

The Earth to Sky Calculus Club is a group of teenagers who live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness. They have launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space. It's a long-running science project that includes astronomy experiments and backcountry adventures.
One weekend, I joined the club to release a high-altitude balloon. We inflated the balloon and watched it rise into the sky. We also watched shooting stars. After the launch, some of the students stayed to watch the stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and gazed at the sky.
It took us a long time to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a cascading waterfall. The camera hadn't recorded any shooting stars. But it was still a great adventure.

Chloe Morgan loves science, especially Palaeontology. She started to be interested in the subject when she was fifteen. It happened by chance when her younger brother was going through the dinosaur phase. Chloe was reluctant to help at first, but she ended up lending him a hand with a science project. She also found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that blew her mind. She knew that this was something she wanted to commit herself to.
Paleontology is not a common career choice for young people, but Chloe was determined to make it her dream. She met her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was famous already despite being quite young. They talked for a while and Chloe felt more at ease. She was worried that he would think she was annoying, but he was patient and willing to listen.
Dinosaurs continue to fascinate us because they speak to the innate explorer in all of us. They are mysterious and there is much to learn about them. Palaeontology is a great form of time travel. It allows us to learn about the past and to appreciate the beauty of the natural world.

**
When you travel by car with your family, even when you're young, you probably know that you're not 'there yet,' even when you ask over and over 'Are we there yet?' It's not 'there' anymore once you get there. It's 'here'. If you really think there's a chance that you're 'there' yet, you should be asking 'Are we here yet?'. And I'm sure there's no one who wishes they were 'there yet' more than the mums and dads fielding that question over and over every single long car trip.
When you're travelling by car, you can have a lot of fun. You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or play puzzles. You can also act as co-pilot and help your parents to keep the car running smoothly. But sometimes, things can go wrong. For example, your brother or sister might put their foot on your side of the seat or start acting out. If this happens, you might get angry and start fighting. But don't worry, your parents will probably be there to help you. They'll yell at your sibling and separate you from them. And once the fighting is over, you can relax and enjoy your trip.

John and Zuzi Morgan have a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They decided to turn their love of tabletop games into a full-time business because there is so much technology and people are busy on their mobile phones and gadgets. The games that are played in their café are called Eurogames. They are known for their gentle themes and easy rules.
One of the most successful Eurogames is Pandemic. It was created by Matt Leacock, a North American designer. Pandemic is a cooperative game where players must work together to solve global problems. It is a popular game because it is easy to learn and fun to play.
The growth of the video games industry has also helped to the popularity of Eurogames. Video games have become more popular than ever before, and this has led to a lot more people being open to playing board games. As a result, tabletop gaming has become more popular than ever before.

**
Jamie Scott is a musician who has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits of recent years. He says his mom was a great singer and that she got him started on the guitar. He started playing music when he was 12 years old and he had to choose between tennis and music. He decided to focus on music because it was his passion. At 17, he left school to try to make it as a performer. He was part of a duo with a friend, but they had to split up because the record labels were only interested in him as a solo act. After a few near misses, he was signed to a music publisher and released a new album. However, fame and fortune did not follow. He had to ask the record label to let him go and switch to another label to release a new album. Writing for others is where he was to really find his feet. He has helped many artists to write songs that have gone to number one.

**
Tony Connor is a popular celebrity who is known for doing stunts on bikes. He is called a 'street trials cyclist.' He often jumps from tall places to land safely in another strange place. His stunts are filmed and posted online.
One Saturday morning, Tony met with me in a BMX park. The local boys all knew exactly who he was. Many older people came to pay their respects to him. Tony is a very courageous and imaginative person. He is willing to take risks to do what he loves.
Despite his fame, Tony is not very interested in social media. He prefers to actually do his stunts rather than discuss them. He also feels that the technology that has made him famous is not always a positive thing.
However, Tony is still grateful for the opportunity to make a living through his passion. He knows that he is lucky to be able to do what he loves.

One of the most interesting things happening in higher education in the UK and around the world is that students are being encouraged to do research earlier in their studies. This means that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists. It can also be done by everyone.
There are different ways to do research. You can do it by reading books, articles, and websites. You can also do it by talking to people and asking questions. If you are a student, you can make a contribution to knowledge by making your own research. You can do this by asking questions, finding answers, and sharing your findings with others.
Critical thinking is an important part of research. It means that you need to be able to think about what you read and hear, test it out, and identify whether it is logical and backed by evidence. You should not just take everything you read or hear as fact. Instead, you should question it and think about it for yourself.

Cities have been centers of intellectual life since the 18th century. They have also been places where people have faced challenges. For example, the same cafes in London that stimulated discussion also spread cholera. The modern city is a place of creativity, but it is also a place where people feel overwhelmed. Scientists have begun to study how the city affects the brain, and the results are alarming. They have found that cities actually dull our thinking, sometimes dramatically so. One of the main reasons for this is the lack of nature in cities. Studies have shown that people who can see trees from their windows recover more quickly from illness. Even small glimpses of nature improve brain performance. The city is full of distractions and requires a lot of attention. It is like a powerful supercomputer that is constantly being overloaded. Natural settings, on the other hand, don't require as much attention. They allow us to relax and replenish our brains. If you are experiencing mental problems, you should consider taking a walk in a natural place.

The mind is a complex thing that takes place inside people's heads. We have neuroimaging techniques to prove it. But the study of the mind should not stop at the skin or the skull. There is evidence that things and neurons participate in human cognitive life. From the viewpoint of archaeology, stone objects, body ornaments, engravings, clay tokens and writing systems play an active role in human evolution and the making of the human mind.
The mind and the brain are often equated. Most of what we know about the human mind has been uncovered through isolating people from the material culture they are usually surrounded by in order to study them. But it often goes unnoticed that much of our thinking takes place outside our heads.
My approach sees the human mind as an unfinished project, in a permanent state of on-going evolution. It is important to keep in mind that whatever actual form the 'stick' might have taken in the history of our species, its primary function was that of a pathway instead of a boundary. Through the 'stick', the human species feels, discovers, and makes sense of the environment, but also enacts the way forward.

Photography has had a significant impact on the United States. It became part of US culture at every level, from the practical and scientific, to the industrial, to the aesthetic. Historians say that photography is arguably the country’s greatest single contribution to the visual arts. In no other art form has US work loomed so large.
Photography has been appealing because it is a mechanical process that matches a growing enthusiasm for technology. It also brought the wonders and sights of the world into the front room with an immediacy that was breathtaking. Additionally, photography has been important for creating and sustaining an impression of self and family, and for representing everyday realities.
If we want to understand a photograph historically, we need to pay attention to its purpose and function within a given cultural matrix. We also need to consider the placement and framing of the image.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician, defined psychology as the 'science of mental life.' This definition is still a good starting point for understanding psychology today. We all have a mental life, so we have some idea about what this means. However, even though the concept can be studied in rats and monkeys as well as humans, it remains a somewhat elusive one.
Psychology is about the mind or brain, but psychologists do not understand nearly enough about its workings to be able to comprehend the part that it plays in the experience and expression of our hopes, fears, and wishes, or in our behaviour during experiences as varied as giving birth or watching a football match.
The endeavour of psychology is much like that involved in solving a crossword puzzle. It involves evaluating and interpreting available clues. Complex interactions are the norm rather than the exception in psychology, and understanding them depends on the development of sophisticated techniques and theories.
Psychology has the same goals as any other science: to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to control or modify the process that it studies. Once these goals have been achieved, it can help us to understand the nature of our experience and come to conclusions that can be applied directly to people’s lives.

In a storehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a museum of failed products. The museum has a collection of products that were withdrawn from sale because nobody wanted to buy them. The proprietor of the museum, Carol Sherry, sees each product as embodying its own sad story. The museum is a viable, profit-making business. It is a testament to the fact that most products fail. The museum was started by ex-marketing man Robert McMath, who intended to accumulate a reference library of consumer products. But he ended up collecting mostly unsuccessful products. The museum is a reminder that we should not be afraid to fail. It is also a reminder that we should not be afraid to try new things.

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But does anyone know why? Most of us probably think we do; after all, it seems obvious. But professional sport is changing faster than at any time in its history and much of what we used to take for granted is now open to question.
There are two main reasons why home advantage exists. First, the home team has the advantage of playing in front of their own crowd. The crowd can generate a lot of noise and energy, which can help the home team to perform better. Second, the home team has the advantage of being familiar with their own environment. They know the stadium, the locker rooms, and the practice facilities. This can give the home team an edge in terms of performance and concentration.
However, there are some changes that have recently occurred that have made home advantage less effective. For example, travel has become much easier, so players are no longer as tired when they travel to away games. Additionally, modern-day stadiums are more similar to each other, so there is less difference in the playing conditions between home and away games.
Despite these changes, home advantage still exists. There are a number of factors that can contribute to home advantage, including the team's spirit, the players' testosterone levels, and the crowd's energy.

The more I practice, the luckier I get, said Gary Player. This quote is famous and is valued by athletes and coaches. However, there are some arguments about who said it first and what it really means. Player didn’t literally mean lucky, he was speaking ironically. He meant that the more you practice, the better you get. Up to a point. Where that point is, is at the heart of the nature-nurture debate. The debate is about whether talent is born or acquired. But it is not a balanced debate. It is more like a basketball game between giants and dwarves. Nurture has been victorious. The theory that expertise in any field can be attained with 10,000 hours’ practice is true. But it is not always the case. There are other factors that can influence success, such as genes, environment, and opportunity.

A recent report found that many children living in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. The reason for this is because they have been spending too much time indoors and not enough time outside. In her book, Kith, Jay Griffiths argues that this is the heart of the problem. She says that children need to be able to roam and explore the natural world. A follow-up study found that a large number of children would be happier if they could simply go outside more. Many adults talk nostalgically about the freedom of their own youth, but they rarely stop to reflect that they are the ones who have imposed that protective regime on their own children. Griffiths believes that children need to take risks and learn from their mistakes.

I am a researcher who has a lot of education and I am good at solving problems. But my schooling has not helped me much with this. Most problems in life cannot be solved with a formula or memorized answers. They require the judgement, wisdom and creative ability that come from life experiences.
For children, those experiences are embedded in play. Play is the natural means by which adults and mammals have always educated themselves. It is also important for children to learn social skills, fairness and morality.
We need to give children more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the horrid trend that has been occurring over the past half century. We must give childhood back to children.

In many countries, there are a lot of young people in their twenties who use social media to find work. There are two popular social networking sites that are often used for job hunting: Twitter and LinkedIn. These sites give people the chance to connect directly with potential employers. However, with greater access to social media comes a greater chance to make mistakes.
For example, a young jobseeker in the US contacted a senior marketing executive via LinkedIn. The marketing executive was not impressed by the young jobseeker's message and sent a rude rejection note. This note has since gone viral. It is a warning to young people about how to use social media for job hunting.
If you are a young person who is looking for a job, there are a few things you should keep in mind. First, you need to be clear and concise in your message. Second, you need to keep the tone humble. Third, you need to be patient and persistent. If you follow these tips, you will be more likely to get a positive response from potential employers.

Newspapers have been struggling in recent years. Their circulation has fallen and they are no longer the main source of news for most people in the US. Some people predict that newspapers will soon be extinct, but history shows that old media have a habit of surviving. Newspapers were once new media, and they became the dominant medium for news in the mid-19th century. However, the internet has changed the way we get news. Now, we can get news online from a variety of sources, including search engines, algorithms, and social media. This makes it easier for people to personalize their news and get the information they need. However, there are still some challenges with online news. For example, it can be difficult to verify the accuracy of information and it can be difficult to find documents or events cited in news stories. Despite these challenges, newspapers still have a lot to offer. They can provide us with information, analysis, and opinion. They can also help us to connect with our community and to learn new things.

**
If humans were truly at home under the light of the moon and stars, we would go in darkness happily. Instead, we are creatures who are adapted to living in the sun’s light. We have engineered the night to receive us by filling it with light. This kind of control has some negative effects called light pollution.
Light pollution is mostly caused by bad lighting design. It washes out the darkness of night, altering light levels and light rhythms to which many forms of life have adapted. It affects migration, reproduction, feeding, and other aspects of life.
We have lit up the night as if it were an unoccupied country. It is as essential to maintaining our biological welfare as light itself. Denying darkness is futile. It causes various physical ailments and messes with our regular sleep-wake cycle.
Living in a glare of our own making, we have cut ourselves off from our evolutionary and cultural heritage. We have forgotten the scale of our being, which is best measured against the dimensions of a deep night with the Milky Way arching overhead.

The founder of a large company recently announced that his company would no longer track employees’ paid holiday time. The company has a lot of employees and provides a variety of services. The founder said that the idea came to him after reading an email from his daughter. The email sounded like it was written by a copywriter from the company's media team.
The founder said that employees can take as much leave as they want, as long as they feel comfortable that their work can be completed on time. However, there are some problems with this policy. First, it is difficult to be sure that all of the work can be completed on time. Second, it can lead to increased guilt and stress for employees. Third, it can lead to pressure from colleagues and office gossip. Fourth, it can lead to a decrease in productivity.
Overall, the founder's policy is not practical. It is too difficult to manage and it will not benefit employees.

Journal-based peer review is a process that ensures the quality of scientific research papers. It is often praised for preventing the publication of flawed or nonsensical papers. However, the process can also be time-consuming, sometimes delaying the publication of a paper by a year. Despite its drawbacks, journal-based peer review remains an essential part of scientific publishing. Preprints, which are drafts of papers that are posted online without having been peer reviewed, are a growing trend that is changing the way scientists publish their work. Preprints bring academics back to the core of research publication, which is to disseminate new results quickly. They also make it easier for researchers to critique and build upon others' work. Preprints have the potential to improve the overall quality of scientific research and make it more accessible to the public.

When I teach literature, students often answer that a poem is like a painting in words. Their answers usually don't satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group to choose an object and write one paragraph describing it empirically, as a scientist might, and another in the first person, from the point of view of the item itself. The exercise led to much amusement and discussion.
A poem is a thing made, like a painting or a machine. Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals or machines, but such comparisons don't always hold up. The most productive thing about trying to define a poem is the debate. Whether you view a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change your conception of what a machine or wild animal is.
A poem is a product of writing and rewriting just like an article, story, or novel. It never really becomes what they usually are – a thing created in order to become a commodity.

**
I bought a metal detector soon after I was married. It cost a lot of money then, but it was worth it. I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, I've found many interesting things. But the most important thing I found was a torc. It's a beautiful necklace of gold and silver. It's very old and rare. I hid it in my wardrobe. I was anxious, but I knew I had to do something. I unscrewed a floorboard and hid the torc underneath. The law says that I have to report the find to the authorities. I carried the torc to the council office. It was authenticated and eventually sold to my local council. The proceeds were split between me and the owner of the field. The torc has been far more than just a lucky windfall. It's something I've saved for the nation.

Sleeping is one of my favorite travel experiences, but I don't talk about it very much because I feel a little guilty. When friends share details of their well-planned trips, I smile and don't say much. What would they think if they knew that my own travel itineraries include naps and lazy mornings. Better sleep is one of travel's happy side effects. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast, I was surprised by how many hours I spent sleeping. There were lots of noisy birds, but it didn't matter. Surrounded by strange smells and sounds, I could plunge into a sleep that was more profound and dream-filled than I imagined possible. Sleep is something else too: it's an experience that changes rhythm, sometimes dramatically, from place to place. People obsess about jet lag, but I suspect that the difficulties I experience recovering from long journeys have more to do with local and cultural adjustment than time zones. When I finally fall into the local sleep pattern, I feel I have truly arrived.

The woman was turning around from the mirror. She was thinking about a hat to wear to her daughter's wedding. Mia, a hat seller, was helping her. Mia knew that the woman was choosing the wrong hat. She offered the woman a lot of hats to try on, but the woman was not satisfied. She was complaining that every other woman would be wearing a hat like that. Mia agreed that the woman would stand out from the crowd. She was also thinking about her own daughter, Jen. It was her thirtieth birthday today and they were having a family get-together. Mia was looking forward to seeing Jen and her family. She was also looking forward to meeting the friend Jen was bringing with her.
The woman was satisfied with the hat that Mia sold her. She was going to wear it to her daughter's wedding. Mia was happy that she had been able to help the woman find the perfect hat.

Lawrence Okoye is a young athlete from London who has traveled a long way to Atlanta, USA, to pursue his dream of playing American football. He has a strong background in discus throwing, but he is now focused on his new journey in the NFL.
Lawrence is still working out the exact responsibilities of his unfamiliar position, but he is determined to make his dream a reality. He has been training hard and he is confident that he will be selected to play in the NFL.
There are a lot of challenges that Lawrence faces, but he is not deterred. He is a patient and resilient person, and he knows that he can accomplish anything he sets his mind to.

**
I was flying east all night and woke up to see that it was already daylight. The landscape below was empty and looked like a dream. I could see no signs of human life and the view was amazing. I shook my head and smiled at my neighbour who woke up and smiled at me. He was a salesman from Moscow who was flying to the outer limits of civilisation. His English was not very good, but I managed to explain to him that I was flying to a city in Siberia. He was not convinced that I could do it. But I explained that I had a lot of warm clothes and that I was going to ride with a friend. We agreed to meet in Siberia. I was working as a geography teacher and I was still far from having full control of my classes, but I was happy with my job. It was frequently challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling and, of course, there were great long holidays in which to chase adventures. I had been working as a geography teacher for a few years and I had used my holidays to go to meet Al. He had decided to do something far more relaxing than teaching: to cycle around the world. I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could deal with each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the sceptics who had told him he could not do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day and it made him feel alive.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots race through a series of pylons between 15 and 25 meters high. The race is very exciting and fast, with speeds of up to 370 kilometers per hour. I was invited to find out what it feels like to take part in the race. Before the flight, I had to sign two forms and learn some important rules. I had to stay calm and focused, and I had to tense up and relax at the right times. The flight was over in 10 minutes, but it was a lot of fun.

Doug Allan is a wildlife cameraman who films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever been amazed by footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it's probably been filmed by him. Allan was born in a cold place and he has a passion for diving and survival in cold places. He became a marine biologist and commercial diver. One day, he was working in Antarctica and a TV crew turned up to film a wildlife documentary. Allan took the crew to different places and after 48 hours, he realized that being a wildlife cameraman ticked all the boxes: travel, adventure, and underwater.
Allan has worked on many major TV wildlife series. He says that it is easier to film today than when he started 35 years ago. Today, you can shoot a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You shot less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.
Allan says that wildlife filming is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. He has had some challenges, but he has also had some amazing experiences. He would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to trek to the North Pole alone and without being resupplied on the way. He swam through cold waters, fought frostbite and polar bears. He also made it to the South Pole the same year. Now he is back in the Arctic preparing for an expedition he says is even more ambitious.
Pen is a strong and determined person. He has a lot of physical endurance and he is also very organized. He is going to set out on a three-month, 1,000 kilometer trek to the North Pole. He will take detailed measurements of the thickness and density of the ice. Nobody has ever done this before. The results of his expedition will be of vital importance to the scientific community.
Pen is married to Mary, a horsewoman. They live in the country with their two children. Pen is worried about being away from his family while he is in the Arctic. He knows that it will be difficult to stay away from his family, but he also knows that his mission is important.
Pen believes his mission reconnects exploration with the search for knowledge that drove previous generations into the unknown. He says, "Making it to the North Pole was ultimately a personal ambition, and of limited value to anyone beyond the polar adventuring community. This time, scientists will profit from the data, and we’re creating a platform in which to engage as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean."

**
I had a break from my training. I was going to do some writing and TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. I also wanted to stay in shape, so I entered marathons and triathlons. There was a race I was thinking about doing, but I was not sure if I was ready. I spoke to some of my rowing colleagues about the race, but they were not very enthusiastic. I knew that if I entered the race, I would want to win. I also had to take into account the cost of the race and the loss of earnings that would result from being away from home. Participating in the race would mean I’d actually be doing something again which I could bring in: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to be thankful for the easy life of a full-time athlete.

Last year, I went to the Arctic Circle in Finland to work with huskies. I was 26 and I was feeling restless. I found a small company run by Anna and Pasi, and they agreed to take me on as a husky dog handler. From December to February, there is plenty of business taking tourists out on sled rides. The dogs are almost hysterical with excitement, straining against the ropes in their desperation to be off. I was able to join the team for three months. The work is very physical and the hours are long. But I am triumphant. I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw. 'In the snow.'

On that day, Radcliffe ran very fast and won the race. The press was there to see her run. They said that her time would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were interested in her treatment, emu oil, which was recommended by Olympic gold medallist, Cathy Freeman.
Radcliffe was surprised that she had won. She felt that it was what she was going to do that day. She and her team had said they weren’t going to set a limit on anything. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team. They were listening to the radio coverage.
Radcliffe began to calculate as she ran. She knew that if she crossed the line in less than three minutes, she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes. She ran very fast and finished the race in 2 hours 16 minutes and 25 seconds.
After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe had won. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, had stayed with her for weeks and provided daily sessions to counter the pain she was experiencing. He said that Radcliffe was one of the most painful athletes he had ever worked with.
Radcliffe did not know that the marathon was her career peak. However, she did leave a lasting legacy. Many women were inspired to take up long-distance running.

When I first started my cooking programme, I was not sure how people would react to it.
