There had been a lot of talk about the food revolution in Britain, and I was certain that we had created a series of programmes that made a genuinely innovative contribution to that. I watched the first programme and was relieved that it was well-received. The success of the show led to many other projects, including a book based on my experiences at the restaurant I own. In each project, there is a sense of being on a journey. I wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each one accompanying its own TV programme of the same name. In these books, the journey was often physical, with passports and suitcases and itineraries. The latest book in the series is called 'In Search of Total Perfection'. It is about meeting extraordinary artisans and exploring new foods. Perfection is subjective. Even the simple task of choosing which dishes to include in the series turned out to be a challenge. Despite the book's title, I knew that I wouldn't be claiming the recipes were definitive. But I reckoned that, by using my technical skill and scientific knowledge, I could pin down some of the things that made these dishes work.

We were driving to Marrakech when the van broke down and crashed into a field. John got out and opened the hood of the car. He stood there for a long time looking at the engine. He said, "Actually, I haven't a clue what I'm doing." Mum and I started to laugh. The field was big and there was nothing in it except grass and flowers. We sat on the side of the road and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away. Mum stretched out on the grass. She asked me to tell her a story. I told her about the birds I heard in London. The tea was very sweet. We stayed at the café all day. When it began to get dark, John said that he would have to have the van towed into Marrakech. We followed John into the hotel. We slept in the garden. The next day, we started to move our van. We watched it being dragged behind a rope. I was worried about how we would get home. I thought it might be easier if we could take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was talking to two other pianists at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were older than her and good enough English speakers. They talked about the pieces they were playing, where else they’d travelled recently, and where they were going next.
Lucy had not wanted to go to the festival, but she had made it. Her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her. Her little brother Gus was excited about the festival. Grace Chang, her teacher, took Lucy out for a special dinner to strategize a repertoire.
In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather turned to her. ‘You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are.’

Your dad might be right. Spending too much time online can be unhealthy. But it can also have some benefits. Generally, research shows that teenagers who use social media have a lot of friends, a good sense of identity and belonging, and are developing the skills they need to be successful in the digital age.
There are a few things that you can do with social media that can help you develop your skills and identity. You can post notices about your favorite music or sports, discover what you enjoy, and connect with others who have similar interests. You can also use social media to collaborate with others to create content and share it with the world.
If you're not outgoing or have a specialized interest, social media can be a great way to connect with others. You can join groups of like-minded people, share your interests, and learn new skills. You can also use social media to build your brand awareness and increase your employability.

When most people think of a family vacation, I guess a road trip through the western states in the US and Canada doesn’t come to mind. However, my parents planned a special vacation this year. They wanted to have a family bonding trip. They said, "Not enough people do this anymore." I was excited, but I was also worried about my privacy. We packed a lot of things into the car, including suitcases, coolers, and clothes. We set off on our journey.
We traveled west and stopped at a town in Oklahoma. The sky was very dark and there was a lot of dust. We learned that cattle get the right-of-way. We continued our journey and stopped at a mountain town in Colorado. It was a beautiful place. We climbed mountains and learned that Jeep roads are best left to Jeep drivers. We also visited a national park and saw a lot of bears.
Our trip was over and I was sad to be home. But I was also happy that I had a lot of new memories. I had a lot of photos to look at and I knew that I would never forget my family vacation.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Her family was separating for two years. Her father had an assignment overseas, and her mother would be joining him, but Rose and her sister Amy were staying in England. Amy was completing her final school courses and would be living under the guardianship of the college Head. It was her last year at school, so it would have been unfair on Amy to move.
Rose was excited about living with her grandmother. There would be lots of dinner invitations, coffee requests, and shopping trips. Her grandmother was not the typical frail old lady figure. She was a social go-getter and had an uncanny knack of bringing people together.
Rose was sensible and very mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, about keeping fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time Rose had insisted on one thing: she wanted her independence. She wanted to play music loud if she wanted, and to invite friends over or go out without having to ask permission every time.
Rose had never been a wild child. Her school reports had always been good and her exam results exemplary. This had worked in her favour. In five weeks’ time, Rose would begin the arduous task of starting at a new school, meeting new friends, forming bonds, and basically beginning her life again.

My name is Charlotte Grainger. My primary school teacher first thought that I might write a novel. I thought that writing a book would be a big achievement and I didn't know what other teenagers were doing. When I turned 13, I decided to attempt writing a novel. The novel I started then is about to be published. It's a big achievement. The narrative is assured and action packed. Nothing about it, except the age of its heroine, suggests that it was written by a teenager.
I was surprised to see a teenager sitting in the office of my publishers. But I knew that I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book. The book is a huge achievement. It's well-written and exciting. I read a lot of books by famous fantasy writers, but I was worried about whether I was capable of writing a book. I also read a book called How Not to Write a Novel. It helped me to understand the basics of writing.
Getting your book published is hard, no matter your age. But I'm grateful for the support I received. I know that writers sink or swim according to their talents. So I don't take things for granted.

Our instructor, Gareth, told us that speed is our friend, not our enemy. We looked down the ski slope and felt nervous. One guy, David, had a lot of experience and he pushed forward, skiing down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp and flew upwards, arms flailing in the air. We held our breath. He hit the ground and flipped head-first into the snow. Gareth said that speed is an unpredictable beast. I didn’t feel like I was cut out for this freestyle stuff. I had enjoyed messing about on previous skiing holidays, but I knew I wasn’t one of those teenagers who spent their time doing freestyle tricks on ramps and half pipes. I was afraid of being ridiculed. But my parents decided to have a winter holiday at a training centre for freestyle skiing in the US. It had a huge indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines, and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. We practised our moves indoors and then headed outside to try them for real. It was difficult to convince my body to go fast enough, but I managed to land properly. I felt like I was walking on air. But that was short-lived. On the final run of the day, I forced myself not to reduce speed as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed appropriately in the landing zone.

Imagine you're riding a rollercoaster in an amusement park. You come to a stop and take a deep breath. Then, the rollercoaster starts to move quickly and turns sharply. Your stomach feels like it's in the air. You feel scared and excited at the same time.
Amusement parks are a big industry. To create the thrills and excitement that guests seek, there are teams of engineers and designers working behind the scenes. It's a challenging job to design a rollercoaster. You have to make sure that the ride is safe and exciting at the same time.
The teams behind rollercoasters must work together to create a strong narrative, be it a space adventure or a high-paced chase in the jungle. They also have to consider the latest advances in technology. But, in the end, gut instincts, years of experience and trial-and-error are what work best.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has accomplished a lot as a choreographer. She creates works for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances from time to time. It's surprising to her that she can fit both activities into her busy schedule.
As a choreographer, Miranda is like a teacher. She enjoys working with young students. She finds it easier to work with students than professionals because they're open to trying new ideas and are hungry for success.
When Miranda starts working with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps and the music dictates what she does. If the dancers aren't responding well to a particular composer's music, that can be frustrating, but she still has to find solutions.
Miranda doesn't like to be attached to one institution. She feels it's valuable to keep establishing contacts with new people. She has to be prepared to adapt the way she works each time she goes somewhere new.
The conversation turns to the recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says that the documentary gives a realistic portrayal of life inside a dance company. She also talks about what makes a great ballet or other dance production.
Miranda has done a wide range of work, so it's hard to categorize her. She doesn't like to be labeled or to have her expertise limited to one area.
